awd_titl_txt: Integrated Photonic Chips for Generating Entangled Photon Triplets
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum information technologies are a driving force for the advancement of fundamental physics and enable large-scale secure communication, unprecedented processor speeds, and higher resolution measurement techniques. These applications require a source of entangled photons, which act as bits of information with interesting quantum properties, as well as circuits that can manipulate and measure these photons. An almost unexplored approach is to generate triplets of entangled photons in a single step. This scheme significantly simplifies the generation of larger entangled states, enabling exciting quantum experiments and filling a huge gap in the development of quantum computers. In this project, the investigator and his students will use titanium dioxide (TiO2) integrated photonic circuits to produce triplets in a robust, scalable, and commercially viable format. Leveraging their expertise in TiO2, nonlinear optics and integrated photonic devices, the group will develop a source that directly produces entangled triplet photons at telecommunications wavelengths. Maturation of TiO2 and photonic integrated quantum circuits will move the field of quantum information science in the direction of commercializable products. While advancing the discoveries in the fields described above, this project will also contribute to the training of future multidisciplinary scientists and engineers through research-based education of undergraduate and graduate students.
 
Quantum information technologies are a driving force for the advancement of fundamental theories and can enable large-scale secure networks, quantum information processors, and enhanced measurement and lithographic techniques. Photonics is an ideal platform for such technologies; however, the generation, manipulation, and detection of single and entangled photons remain a challenge. While sources of spontaneous single and pairs of photons are widespread, triplet-photon sources are almost completely unexplored and represent the missing link for fundamental tests in quantum theory and heralded photon pairs for quantum communication and computation. Furthermore, a triplet-photon source significantly simplifies the generation of larger entangled states. This project will seek to developm a source that can directly produce entangled triplet photons at telecommunications wavelengths (e.g., 1500 nm) at a rate of 4,000 triplets/sec (six orders of magnitude greater than current experimental efforts) using third-order spontaneous parametric down-conversion. By coupling to a resonant cavity, the group will further enhance the emission rate by an additional order of magnitude and improve spectral control. TiO2 is the ideal material for this process because of its high transparency, large nonlinearity, high linear refractive indices, and negligible fluorescence. The group will exploit the strong, sustained nonlinearity and tight light-confinement in TiO2 devices to achieve unprecedented triplet-photon generation rates directly on chip, where they can readily be routed, manipulated, and then measured using integrated detectors.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum information technologies show exciting promise for the advancement of fundamental theories and can enable large-scale secure networks, higher resolution measurement techniques, and exponentially faster computing to solve unanswered questions from cancer research to economics.

Nanophotonics, the combination of nanotechnology and the study of light, is an ideal platform for such technologies. Single photons, representing quantum bits (qubits), generated inside photonic materials can be manipulated using free-space optics, fiber optics and integrated circuit technology. While sources of spontaneous single and pairs of photons are nearly ubiquitous, direct generation of three entangled photons is almost completely unexplored and represents the missing link for fundamental tests in quantum theory and heralded photon pairs for quantum communication and computation. In addition, a triplet-photon source drastically simplifies the generation of larger entangled states necessary for complex operations and practical applications.

Direct triplet production through third-order spontaneous parametric down-conversion (TOSPDC), a χ(3) process whereby one photon is annihilated to directly produce a photon triplet, is challenging due to extraordinarily low efficiency in bulk materials. The low efficiency of TOSPDC in bulk materials is due to low intrinsic χ(3) nonlinearities (compared to χ(2)), weak light confinement, short interaction lengths, and difficulties achieving momentum conservation between widely-spaced wavelengths.

Titanium Dioxide (TiO2) nanophotonics can address the challenges of direct triplet-photon generation. TiO2 has a high transparency, large χ(3) nonlinearity, high linear refractive indices, and negligible fluorescence. Based on these parameters, we can tightly focus laser beams inside TiO2-based nanophotonic structures to produce strong and sustained light-matter interactions that generate triplet photons via TOSPDC. In addition, we can build on our previous work developing integrated nanophotonic circuits based on TiO2 to manipulate and route entangled photons to carry out quantum information operations.

Our approach consists of developing devices that  directly generate entangled photon triplets at telecommunications wavelengths (e.g., 1500 nm) from a visible pump photon (e.g., 500 nm) using TOSPDC. Our proposed platform can directly produce entangled triplet photons at a theoretical rate of 4000 triplets/s, which is six orders of magnitude greater than current experimental efforts. In order to observe this rate, we have addressed a number of challenges in design, fabrication and measurement of our devices.

We design our devices using Lumerical MODE Solutions software. First, we input data from measuring the optical properties of TiO2 thin layers that we grow in the Center for Nanoscale Systems (CNS) cleanroom facility using RF sputtering. Second, we determine the conditions under which TOSPDC can occur based on energy and momentum conservation. Finally, we output the data indicating the efficiency of our devices for specific dimensions.

We proceed to fabricate our devices based on the most efficient device dimensions. Out top-down approach is to apply a pattern to our TiO2 layer using electron-beam lithography and then to etch away the parts of TiO2 to achieve roughly rectangular structures. Finally we cover our devices with a protective cladding layer of silica.

We characterize the optical properties of our nanoscale devices using third-harmonic generation (THG). THG is the reverse process of TOSPDC and is guided by the same energy and momentum constraints, but is much simpler to measure. This allows us to test our devices by observing the THG brightness, length of propagation along the length of the device, and the wavelength produced. We take our best devices to Lincoln Labs, where we have established a partnership for using high-efficiency detectors to measure the entangled photons generated via TOSPDC. The output of these measurements is collected over multiple days and analyzed for statistically significant correlations that indicate the presence of triplet photons.

We have addressed many of the challenges and achieved many of the necessary steps toward measuring entangled photon triplets generated directly via TOSPDC in integrated TiO2 nano-scale waveguides. We have expanded on our device design methods, improved our material growth and fabrication procedure, gained a clearer understanding of the entangled states we expect to produce, and devised better characterization techniques that allow us to select the most efficient devices for correlation measurements.
